comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Women in pubs! At this time this would have been VERY unusual in Irish society.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content: The closet in the left corner at the back is some sort of musical organ!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hab3045] That's what it looks like alright - with a cylinder for playing music?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] But was this really a pub? I'm wondering if during the day, it operated also as a waiting room for "facilities of locomotion" as I saw transport described in an 1891 Dublin guide... And they're not unaccompanied either, which was surely the greatest transgression back in the day.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Oh this is a cracker! They look so formal! I have to head out but I will be back to see what this is.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: It would depend on whether it was just a "Saloon" or a "Saloon Bar".

comment.author: 66340104@N05
comment._content:
The wild nights in Larne.................

It looks more like a dining/function room, with the organ for dances.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: I think we need to be carefull attributing modern definitions to the description "Saloon"

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Could be a saloon in the sense of "no standing upper saloon", rather than a pub.

comment.author: 56225952@N06
comment._content: The instrument at the back is surely a Pianola (and a rather elaborate one at that) and is an early form of a jukebox playing popular airs of the day (and amazingly, hymns) for a small fee.  It is probably similar to the one in Bella Cohen's brothel in the Circe episode of James Joyces's "Ulysses" where, at the climax of the episode,  it plays 'My Girl's a Yorkshire Girl" at a cost of 2d. Thankyou for posting this image it's fascinating.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56225952@N06] It's a barrel organ or mechanical organ rather than a pianola, but the principle's the same.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: A Barrel Organ. Probably sounded a bit like this - youtu.be/aKNWHXlWRig [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] 19 seconds earlier!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Looks like it's one of these: www.flickr.com/photos/johngoes/2938816458/ Different doors though.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: That one is in the automated musical instrument museum in Bruchsal but there's no details of it on their website. www.landesmuseum.de/website/Deutsch/Sammlungsausstellunge...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, something beginning with C!!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 51739479@N02
comment._content: Yes I was surprised to see the two women especially the one who may be on her own...although perhaps she is with the man who seems to be sitting with his back to her!

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Not sure what you think that is but it's a bit narrow to be the obvious C that would have everyone in there done up to the nines.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: We had a temperance resaturant at the cork Exhibition now a temperance saloon in Larne...........

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] It's not a coffee mill. The bit that looks like a handle is actually the stanchion in the wall behind it.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Most of them are wearing hats indoors, probably waiting for the Bianconi Mail car.

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: 5 to 1

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/80413507@N08] good point

comment._content: Cheese? I doubt it.

comment.author: 79549245@N06

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Yes, yes. Don't go spoiling the suspense.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/bariom43] I think she may be with him, but they just weren't getting on that day.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66340104@N05] I've been in Larne after 6:00 pm - wild nights?  Don't think so!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I just searched for things beginning with C in the nli archive, and there are lots in the Clonbrock collection, but not the Lawrence collection.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Are those stanchions or the piping for gas lamps?  This is almost certainly a waiting room for transport given the stances of the patrons though it was almost certainly a temperance or "dry" hotel.  Note the camera covered witht he black cloth reflected in the mirror at the other end of the saloon!  Fabulous shot.

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: The wildest thing in Larne at night is asking for chilli sauce on a burger from The Station Supper Saloon! I haven't set foot in the place in 20 years but it hasn't changed much! maps.google.co.uk/maps?q=larne&hl=en&ll=54.849709...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] That's exactly the C! I don't think we've ever caught sight of a camera in any of our Lawrence photos before - huzzah for mirrors!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Unfortunately out of all of our "Saloon" photos, have none of the Station Supper Saloon...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Some may have read it before, but there's a nice few lines from the Larne Millennium Initiative about McNeill's, the tourists, etc. Even a note about his "driver" (who may be the chap pictured with the car - who looks like he stepped away from the tiller for the photo)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] So sorry all, I was late to the game, didn't see the notes and spoiled the guessing game that was going on.  Bang head three times against the wall as penance!  Won't damage the head whatever about the wall!

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content:
Ha I spotted the organ before anyone else.
I will be expecting my cake shortly. ;)

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Can we see Mr Mc Neill's other hotel at Garron Tower?

comment.author: 66340104@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] According to the Rough Guide the best view of Larne is in your rear view mirror....................!

comment.author: 80413507@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] And you even gave us a hint! (Wood from thre trees comes to mind!)

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: ROFL at some of the comments! But no photographer with the C! But these things were so posed given the exposure times then, which probably explains the upright postures. (well that and the corsets! - hard to have wild nights out wearing corsets!)

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: It used to be that the greatest thing to come out of Larne was the Stranraer ferry!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Is that the big castley (technical term) one?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Not the Stranraer Ferry! Is Mr McNeill's other hotel the huge castle I'm seeing in some of our photos?

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Yes it is - www.stmacnissis.com/ Now a school.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66340104@N05] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] It has been said of Larne that the best view is in the rear view mirror, or that the best thing to come out of Larne is the road to Belfast. I don't know how true it is, but I'm told that Larne Tourism (not an oxymoron - see here) once put in their literature - "Larne is best seen from a distance"!

comment.author: 59302818@N00
comment._content: Looks like the figures were posing especially for the photograph.  The women all look like  'Old Mother Reilly'

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/crexcrex] They look like they're at a wake (which is why I affected to believe that everyone thought the C was a coffin).

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Can't be a wake they are all too sober looking!

comment._content: great shot

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Cheerful looking lot....not!
